sen.j: 北條 早雲 / 伊勢 盛時（ほうじょう そううん / いせ もりとき）は、室町時代中後期（戦国時代 (日本)初期）の武将で、戦国大名となった後北条氏の祖である。
sen.e: Soun HOJO (AKA Moritoki ISE) was a military commander during the mid to late Muromachi Period in the Age of Civil Wars, and he was the patriarch of warring lord of Go-Hojo clan.

Soun HOJO (also known as Moritoki ISE) was a military commander during the mid to late Muromachi Period, and the patriarch of the Go-Hojo (or Late Hojo) Clan, a powerful warrior clan of the Warring States Period.
sen.cmt: "AKA"→"also known as""Age of Civil Wars"→"Warring States Period"Deleted "he was"Added "(or Late Hojo)"Capitalized "c"Deleted "warring lord "
sen.e: Soun HOJO (also known as Moritoki ISE) was a military commander during the mid to late Muromachi Period, and the patriarch of the Gohojo clan (or Late Hojo), a powerful warrior clan of the Warring States Period.
sen.cmt: 後北条氏→the Gohojo clan (or Late Hojo)

sen.j: 伊勢 宗瑞（いせ そうずい）とも呼ばれる。
sen.e: He was also called Sozui ISE.
He was also called Sozui ISE.
He was also called Sozui ISE.

sen.j: 北條早雲は戦国大名の嚆矢であり、早雲の活動は東国の戦国時代の端緒として歴史的意義がある。
sen.e: Soun HOJO was a leading figure among the warring lords, and his achievements are historically meaningful in that they triggered the warring period.
Soun HOJO was a leading figure among the warring lords, and his achievements are historically significant in that they triggered the Warring States Period in the eastern provinces.
sen.cmt: "meaningful"→"significant""warring period"→"Warring States Period in the eastern provinces"
sen.e: Soun HOJO was a leading figure among the warring lords, and his achievements are historically significant in that they triggered the Warring States Period in the eastern provinces.

sen.j: 諱は長らく長氏（ながうじ）と伝えられてきたが、現在では盛時（もりとき）が定説となっている（出自節を参照）。
sen.e: It is said that his real name was Nagauji, which was rarely used, and today, Moritoki is the commonly accepted name (see section on Place of Birth).
His real name was long said to be Nagauji but today, Moritoki is the commonly accepted name (see section on Place of Birth).
sen.cmt: Reworded first part of sentenceDeleted "which was rarely used" - not in original
sen.e: His real name was long said to be Nagauji but today, Moritoki is the commonly accepted name (see section on Origins).
sen.cmt: 下記の「出自」節表記に合わせて「Place of Birth」→「Origins」

sen.j: 通称は新九郎（しんくろう）。
sen.e: Soun was called Shinkuro as a boy.
His childhood name was Shinkuro.
His childhood name was Shinkuro.

sen.j: 戒名は早雲庵宗瑞（そううんあんそうずい）。
sen.e: His posthumous Buddhist name is Soun-An-Sozui.
His posthumous Buddhist name was Soun-An-Sozui.
sen.cmt: "is"→"was" - although "is" is literally correct, "was" sounds more natural.
sen.e: His posthumous Buddhist name was Sounan Sozui.

sen.j: 生年は長らく永享4年（1432年）が定説とされてきたが、近年新たに康正2年（1456年）説が提唱されている。
sen.e: It was long believed that his year of birth was 1432; however, recent studies advocates his birth year to be 1456.
Although it has long been believed that he was born in 1432, recent theories have suggested the year 1456.
sen.cmt: "his year of birth was"→"he was born in""studies advocates his birth year to be"→"theories have suggested the year"
sen.e: Although it has long been believed that he was born in 1432, recent theories have suggested the year 1456.

sen.j: 伊勢家が北条姓を称したのは盛時の嫡男・氏綱のときであるが、通例では伊勢盛時も遡って「北条早雲」と呼ばれる。
sen.e: Ise family changed its last name to HOJO during the time Moritoki's son Ujitsuna was active; and, Soun HOJO is commonly used retroactive to the time he was called Moritoki ISE.
The ISE family name was changed to HOJO by Moritoki's son, Ujitsuna, and Soun HOJO, rather than Moritoki ISE, is the name commonly used.
sen.cmt: "changed its last name to HOJO during the time"→"name was changed to HOJO by"Deleted "was active"
sen.e: The Ise family name was changed to Hojo by Moritoki's son, Ujitsuna, and Soun HOJO, rather than Moritoki ISE, is the name commonly used.

sen.j: 従って、盛時の存命中に「北条早雲」の名が使われたことは無い。
sen.e: Therefore, Moritoki never used the name Soun HOJO during his lifetime.
However, Moritoki never used the name Soun HOJO during his lifetime.
However, Moritoki never used the name Soun HOJO during his lifetime.

sen.j: 一介の素浪人から戦国大名にのし上がった下剋上の典型とするのが長く通説とされてきた。
sen.e: It has long been believed that Soun was a classic example of one a master-less samurai, climbing up the ladder to warlord.
Soun has long been seen as a classic example of a ronin (masterless samurai) climbing up the ladder to become a daimyo.
Soun has long been seen as a classic example of a ronin (masterless samurai) climbing up the ladder to become a daimyo.

sen.j: しかし、実際には室町幕府の政所執事を務めた伊勢氏の出自とみられる。
sen.e: However, it is also believed that he was a member of the Ise clan holding public office in the Muromachi Shogunate.
However, it is also believed that he was a member of the Ise Clan that held public office in the Muromachi Shogunate.
However, it is also believed that he was a member of the Ise clan that held public office in the Muromachi Shogunate.

sen.j: 1950年代に発表された藤井論文以降、伊勢氏のうちで備中国に居住した支流で、備中国荏原庄（現井原市）で生まれたという説が有力となり、その後の資料検証によって備中荏原荘の半分を領する領主（300貫といわれる）であることがほぼ確定した。
sen.e: Since the Fujii Theory was published in 1950, the most popular theory states that Soun was in the Ise faction residing in the Province of Bitchu, born in the village of Ebara (currently Ihara City), and a study of other documents has basically determined that he was a feudal lord owning half of Bitchu Ebara (300 kan, a unit of rice weight before the koku system).

Since the Fujii Theory was published in the 1950s, the most popular theory states that Soun was born in the village of Ebara (modern day Ihara City) into a branch of the Ise Clan residing in the Province of Bitchu, and the study of other documents has basically determined that he was a feudal lord owning half of Bitchu Ebara (worth 300 kan, a unit of rice weight used before the koku system).

Since the Fujii Theory was published in the 1950s, the most popular theory states that Soun was born in the village of Ebara (modern day Ihara City) into a branch of the Ise clan residing in the Province of Bitchu, and the study of other documents has basically determined that he was a feudal lord owning half of Bitchu Ebara (worth 300 kan, a unit of rice weight used before the koku system).

sen.j: 室町幕府申次衆の書状と駿河国関連の書状において照らし合わせたところ、記載された史料の「伊勢新九郎盛時」なる人物が同一である事も決め手となった。
sen.e: When checking with the documents left by the civil servants in the Muromachi Shogunate and the document related to the Province of Suruga, it has been confirmed that both of these historical document listed Ise-Shinkuro-Moritoki, which supports the above theory.
Documents left by the civil servants of the Muromachi Shogunate and documents related to the Province of Suruga both mention a certain "Ise-Shinkuro-Moritoki", which supports the above theory.
sen.cmt: Deleted "When checking with the" and "the""in"→"of"Made 2nd "document" pluralReworded 2nd part of sentence
sen.e: Documents left by the civil servants of the Muromachi Shogunate and documents related to the Province of Suruga both mention a certain 'Shinkuro Moritoki ISE,' which supports the above theory.
sen.cmt: 原文の「」に合わせ"を'にIse-Shinkuro-Moritoki→Shinkuro Moritoki ISE

sen.j: 従来の説は文献の解釈の違いによるところが大きく、さらに「備中伊勢氏」説は史料が最も豊富で多岐にわたる事も出自解明に寄与した。
sen.e: The conventionally accepted theory differed due to how documents were interpreted; however, the theory that Soun was in the Ise clan of Bitchu is noted in the majority of historical documents, leading it to being accepted as his origin.
Theories differed depending on how documents were interpreted but since the majority of them note that Soun was from the Ise Clan of Bitchu, this has become an accepted fact.
Theories differed depending on how documents were interpreted but since the majority of them note that Soun was from the Ise clan of Bitchu, this has become an accepted fact.

sen.j: 近年の研究で早雲の父・伊勢盛定が幕府政所執事伊勢貞親と共に八代将軍足利義政の申次衆として重要な位置にいた事も明らかになってきている。
sen.e: In the recent studies, it has become clear that Soun's father, Morisada ISE, and Sadachika ISE held important positions in the Muromachi Shogunate fulfilling the duty of announcing the arrival of visitors to the 8th Shogun, Yoshimasa ASHIKAGA.

Recent studies have shown that Soun's father, Morisada ISE, and Sadachika ISE held important positions in the Muromachi Shogunate, fulfilling the duty of announcing the arrival of visitors to the 8th Shogun, Yoshimasa ASHIKAGA.
sen.cmt: "In the recent studies, it has become clear"→"Recent studies have shown"
sen.e: Recent studies have shown that Soun's father, Morisada ISE, and Sadachika ISE held important positions in the Muromachi Shogunate, fulfilling the duty of announcing the arrival of visitors to the 8th Shogun, Yoshimasa ASHIKAGA.

sen.j: 早雲は伊勢盛定と京都伊勢氏当主で政所執事の伊勢貞国の娘との間に生まれた。
sen.e: Soun was born the son of Morisada ISE and the daughter of Sadachika ISE, the head of Ise clan in Kyoto who held an upper-ranking post in the government.
Soun was born between Morisada ISE and the daughter of Sadakuni ISE, the head of Ise Clan in Kyoto who held an upper-ranking post in the government.
Soun was born between Morisada ISE and the daughter of Sadakuni ISE, the head of Ise clan in Kyoto who held an upper-ranking post in the government.

sen.j: 決して身分の低い素浪人ではない。
sen.e: Therefore, he was not a lowly master-less samurai.
Therefore, he was not a lowly ronin.
Therefore, he was not a lowly ronin.

sen.j: 早雲は盛定の所領、備中荏原荘で生まれ、若年時はここに居住したと考えられる。
sen.e: Soun was born in Bitchu Ebara area, owned by Morisada, and was known to have been raised there as a young boy.
Soun was born in the Bitchu Ebara area, owned by Morisada, and is thought to have been raised there as a young boy.
Soun was born in the Bitchu Ebara area, owned by Morisada, and is thought to have been raised there as a young boy.

sen.j: 荏原荘には文明 (日本)3年（1471年）付けの「平盛時」の署名の禁制が残されている（ただし、花押が後のものとは異なる）。
sen.e: In Ebara, there remains prohibition laws signed by Kiyomori TAIRA dated 1471 (The Kao Code signature is different to ones found later).
In Ebara, there remain prohibition laws signed by Moritoki TAIRA dated 1471 (The Kao Code signature is different to ones found later).
In Ebara, there remain prohibition laws signed by Moritoki TAIRA dated 1471 (The Kao Code signature is different to ones found later).

sen.j: さらに、備中国からは大道寺氏、内藤氏、笠原氏など、後北条氏の家臣が出ている。
sen.e: The Daidoji, Naito and Kasahara clans that served the Go-Hojo clan also originated in Bitchu.
The Daidoji, Naito and Kasahara clans that served the Go-Hojo clan also originated in Bitchu.
The Daidoji, Naito and Kasahara clans that served the Gohojo clan also originated in Bitchu.

tit.e: Civil Servant and Military Posts in Muromachi Shogunate
Civil Servant and Military Posts in the Muromachi Shogunate
Civil Servant and Military Posts in the Muromachi Shogunate

sen.j: 応仁元年（1467年）応仁の乱が起こり、駿河守護今川義忠が上洛して東軍に加わった。
sen.e: In 1467, the Onin War broke out, and Yoshitada IMAGAWA, in the post of guard at Suruga, came to Kyoto to join the force.
In 1467, the Onin War broke out, and Yoshitada IMAGAWA, the Shugo (Governor) of Suruga, came to Kyoto to join the eastern army.
sen.cmt: "in the post of guard at"→"the Shugo (Governor) of""force"→"eastern army"
sen.e: In 1467, the Onin War broke out, and Yoshitada IMAGAWA, the Shugo (Governor) of Suruga, came to Kyoto to join the eastern army.

sen.j: 義忠はしばしば伊勢貞親を訪れており、その申次を早雲の父盛定が務めている。
sen.e: Yoshitada had often visited Sadachika ISE, and it was Soun's father, Morisada, who had received and announced his arrival.
Yoshitada had often visited Sadachika ISE, and it was Soun's father, Morisada, who had received and announced his arrival.
Yoshitada had often visited Sadachika ISE, and it was Soun's father, Morisada, who had received and announced his arrival.

sen.j: その縁で早雲の姉（または妹）の北川殿が義忠と結婚したと考えられる。
sen.e: It was these meetings that led to the marriage of Yoshitada and Soun's sister, Kitagawa-Dono.
It was these meetings that led to the marriage of Yoshitada and Soun's sister, Kitagawa-Dono.
It was these meetings that led to the marriage of Yoshitada and Soun's sister, Kitagawa-dono.

sen.j: 早雲が素浪人とされていた頃は北川殿は側室であろうとされていたが、備中伊勢氏は今川氏と家格的に遜色なく、近年では正室であると見られている。
sen.e: When Soun was thought to be a master-less samurai, Kitagawa-Dono was said to be Yoshitada's mistress; however, ranks of the Ise and Imagawa clans were equivalent, and so recently, the theory has been revised to state that Kitagawa-Dono was Yoshitada's legal wife, not his mistress.

When Soun was thought to be a ronin, Kitagawa-Dono was said to be Yoshitada's mistress; however, the Ise and Imagawa Clans were of equivalent rank and so recently, the theory has been revised to state that Kitagawa-Dono was Yoshitada's legal wife, not his mistress.
sen.cmt: "masterless samurai"→"ronin""ranks of the Ise and Imagawa clans were equivalent"→"the Ise and Imagawa Clans were of equivalent rank"
sen.e: When Soun was thought to be a ronin, Kitagawa-dono was said to be Yoshitada's mistress; however, the Ise and Imagawa clans were of equivalent rank and so recently, the theory has been revised to state that Kitagawa-dono was Yoshitada's legal wife, not his mistress.

sen.j: 文明5年（1473年）に北川殿は嫡男龍王丸（後の今川氏親）を生んだ。
sen.e: In 14673, Kitagawa-Dono gave birth to a son, Tatsu-o-maru (later the name was changed to Ujichika IMAGAWA)
In 1473, Kitagawa-Dono gave birth to a son, Tatsu-o-maru (who later took the name Ujichika IMAGAWA)
sen.cmt: Deleted '6'"later the name was changed to"→"who later took the name"
sen.e: In 1473, Kitagawa-dono gave birth to a son, Tatsuomaru (who later took the name Ujichika IMAGAWA).

sen.j: 京都で早雲は将軍義政の弟の足利義視に仕えたとされるが、近年有力視される康正2年（1456年）生まれとすると、義視が将軍後継者と擬されていた時期（1464年-1467年）には10歳前後で幼すぎ、応仁元年（1467年）以降、義視は西軍に走っている。
sen.e: In Kyoto, Soun is said to have served Yoshimi ASHIKAGA, younger brother to Shogun Yoshimasa; however, if Soun had been born in 1456, the recent theory considered most popular today, he would have been only 10 years old during the period Yoshimi was considered to be the next Shogun (1464-1467), and Yoshimi had changed sides to the East force after 1467.

In Kyoto, Soun is said to have served Yoshimi ASHIKAGA, the younger brother of Shogun Yoshimasa, though if Soun had been born in 1456, as the most popular recent theories contend, he would have been only 10 years old during the period Yoshimi was in line to be the next Shogun (1464-1467), and Yoshimi had changed sides to the western army after 1467.
sen.cmt: Added "the", "of""; however,"→", though""the recent theory considered most popular today"→"as the most popular recent theories contend""considered to be the next Shogun"→"in line to be the next Shogun""East force"→"western army"
sen.e: In Kyoto, Soun is said to have served Yoshimi ASHIKAGA, the younger brother of Shogun Yoshimasa, although if Soun had been born in 1456, as the most popular recent theories contend, he would have been only 10 years old during the period Yoshimi was in line to be the next shogun (1464-1467), and Yoshimi had changed sides to the western army after 1467.
sen.cmt: next Shogun→next shogunthough→although に変更しました。

sen.j: このため、これを疑問視する見方もある。
sen.e: Considering this fact, some view the theory as questionable.
Considering this fact, some view this date as questionable.
Considering this fact, some view this date as questionable.

sen.j: 「伊勢新九郎盛時」の名は文明13年（1481年）から文書に現れる。
sen.e: The name Ise-Shinkuro-Moritoki comes out in documents written in 1481 and thereafter.
The name Ise-Shinkuro-Moritoki appears in documents from 1481 onwards.
The name Shinkuro Moritoki ISE appears in documents from 1481 onwards.

sen.j: 文明15年（1481年）に将軍足利義尚の申次衆に任命されている。
sen.e: In 1481, Soun was appointed civil servant to Shogun Yoshihisa ASHIKAGA.
In 1483, Soun was appointed civil servant to Shogun Yoshihisa ASHIKAGA.
sen.cmt: Although Japanese original has "文明15年（1481年）", 文明15年 was actually 1483, so changed accordingly
sen.e: In 1483, Soun was appointed civil servant to Shogun Yoshihisa ASHIKAGA.

sen.j: 長享元年（1487年）奉公衆となる。
sen.e: He was appointed to a military post in 1481.
He was appointed to a military post in 1487.
He was appointed to a military post in 1487.

sen.j: 京で幕府に出仕している間、早雲は建仁寺と大徳寺で禅を学んでいる。
sen.e: While Soun was working for the Bakufu government in Kyoto, he studied zen at Kennin-ji Temple and Daitoku-ji Temple.
While Soun was working for the Bakufu government in Kyoto, he studied Zen at Kennin-ji Temple and Daitoku-ji Temple.
While Soun was working for the bakufu government in Kyoto, he studied Zen at Kennin-ji Temple and Daitoku-ji Temple.

tit.e: Return to the Province of Suruga
Return to the Province of Suruga

sen.j: 文明8年（1476年）今川義忠は遠江国の塩売坂の戦いで西軍の遠江守護斯波義廉方の国人横地氏、勝間田氏の襲撃を受けて討ち死にした。
sen.e: In 1476, Yoshitada IMAGAWA was attacked and killed by the West Force led by the Yokichi and Katsumata clans, guards of the Province of Totoumi serving Yoshikado SHIBA, at the Battle of Shiouri-zaka in Totoumi.
sen.cmt: 遠江国等Province of Totoumiとすると同じ事の繰り返しで邪魔なので、初出のみProvinceを入れてその後は臨機応変にＰｒｏvince を入れたり、Totoumiだけ使用してます。
sen.e: In 1476, at the Battle of Shiouri-zaka in the Province of Totoumi, Yoshitada IMAGAWA was attacked and killed by the western army's Yokichi and Katsumata Clans, who served the Governor of Totoumi, Yoshikado SHIBA.

In 1476, at the Battle of Shiouri-zaka in Totomi Province, Yoshitada IMAGAWA was attacked and killed by the western army's Yokichi and Katsumata clans, who served the Governor of Totomi, Yoshikado SHIBA.

sen.j: しかし、遠江国の政情は複雑で、近年の研究ではこれらの国人は東軍の斯波義良に属するものだと考察されており、義忠は同じ東軍と戦っていたことになってしまう。
sen.e: The governing status of Totoumi was complicated and recent study has revealed that clans serving Totoumi actually belonged to Yoshinaga SHIBA in the East Force, which meant that Yoshitada was fighting the East Force.

However, the political situation in Totoumi was complicated and recent studies have shown that these clans were actually under the command of Yoshinaga SHIBA of the eastern army, which means that Yoshitada was fighting the eastern, not the western, army.

sen.e: However, the political situation in Totomi Province was complicated and recent studies have shown that these clans were in fact under the command of Yoshinaga SHIBA of the eastern army, which means that Yoshitada was fighting the eastern, not the western, army.
sen.cmt: 遠江国→Totomi Provinceactually→in factに変更しました。

sen.j: 残された嫡男龍王丸は幼少であり（異説あり）、このため今川氏の家臣三浦氏、朝比奈氏などが一族の小鹿範満（義忠の従兄弟）を擁立して、家中が二分される家督争いとなった。
sen.e: When Yoshitada died, his son, Tatsu-o-maru was still young (other theories exist), and the retainers Miura clan and Asahina clan tried to bring Norimitsu OSHIKA (Yoshitada's cousin) to their side, dividing the Imagawa clan in two.

When Yoshitada died, his son, Tatsu-o-maru, was still young (other theories exist), so retainers such as the Miura and Asahina Clans backed Norimitsu OSHIKA (Yoshitada's cousin), dividing the Imagawa clan in two.

sen.e: When Yoshitada died, his son, Tatsuomaru, was still young (other theories exist), so retainers such as the Miura and Asahina clans backed Norimitsu OSHIKA (Yoshitada's cousin), dividing the Imagawa clan in two.

sen.j: これに堀越公方と扇谷上杉氏が介入し、それぞれ執事の上杉政憲と家宰の太田道灌を駿河国へ兵を率いて派遣させた。
sen.e: Horigoe Kubo and the Ogigayatsu-Uesugi clan intervened and dispatched forces led by their higher-ranking officers, Masanori UESUGI and Dokan OTA, to the Province of Suruga.
Horigoe Kubo and the Ogigayatsu-Uesugi Clan intervened and dispatched forces led by their higher-ranking officers, Masanori UESUGI and Dokan OTA, to the Province of Suruga.

sen.j: 範満と上杉政憲は血縁があり、また太田道灌も史料に範満の「合力」と記されている。
sen.e: Norimitsu and Masanori UESUGI were related by blood, and Dokan OTA has also noted in historical documents that he was on the side of Norimitsu.
Norimitsu and Masanori UESUGI were related by blood, and Dokan OTA is also recorded as having supported Norimitsu.

sen.e: Norimitsu and Masanori UESUGI were related by blood, and Dokan OTA is also recorded as having supported Norimitsu.

sen.j: 龍王丸派にとって情勢は不利であった。
sen.e: Tatsu-o-maru was at the disadvantage.
Tatsu-o-maru's supporters was at the disadvantage.
Tatsuomaru's supporters was at the disadvantage.

sen.j: 北川殿の弟（または兄）である早雲は駿河国へ下り、調停を行い龍王丸が成人するまで範満を家督代行とすることで決着させた。
sen.e: Being Kitagawa-Dono's brother, Soun went to Suruga to mediate between the two forces and worked it out so that Norimitsu would reign over the family on Tatsu-o-maru's behalf until Tatsu-o-maru came of age.

Being Kitagawa-Dono's brother, Soun went to Suruga to mediate between the two forces and worked it out so that Norimitsu would reign over the family on Tatsu-o-maru's behalf until Tatsu-o-maru came of age.

sen.e: Historian Motoki KURODA questions the date on account of Akisada Yamauchi-Uesugi's letter, in which it is written that Yamauchi-Uesugi clan attacked a stronghold thought to be the Odawara-jo Castle in 1496, and listed among the forces with Ogigayatsu-Uesugi were Fujiyori OMORI and Soun's younger brother Yajiro ISE; therefore, Soun's capture of Odawara-jo Castle must have occurred thereafter.

sen.e: There is also a document stating that on March 28, 1501, Soun exchanged one of the villages he ruled for the land on which Izusan-jinja Shrine stood and which was under the jurisdiction of Odawara-jo Castle, meaning that Soun was already ruling over Odawara-jo Castle at that time.

sen.e: Historical novels often include the story of Soun HOJO as a master-less samurai in his later life who went to Suruga seeking help from his younger sister, a mistress to a Shogun guard, and rose to become the ruler of the Kanto area

sen.j: 江戸時代前期までは後北条氏は名門伊勢氏の出と考えられていた様子だが、江戸時代中期以降、『太閤記』の影響で戦国時代を身分の低い者が実力で身を興す「下克上の時代」ととらえる史観が民衆の願望もあいまって形成され,明治時代になって定着し、戦後まで続いた。
sen.e: Apparently, the Go-hojo clan was thought to have originated from the Ise clan until the beginning of Edo Period; however, from Mid-Edo Period, a novel "Taikoki" came out, which revised Soun as a lowly samurai in the Warring State Period, who came to power through his achievements in the so called "Gekokujo Period."

sen.e: Some of the historical figures presented as lowly samurai climbing up the social ladder are Soun HOJO, Dosan SAITO and Hideyoshi TOYOTOMI; and Soun born as a lowly samurai became the conventional theory.

sen.j: 早雲の出自については長年明らかにならず、主なものに、大和国在原説、山城国宇治説、伊勢説、京都説、備中説があった。
sen.e: Soun's place of birth remained unknown for a long time and some of the most accepted theories are that he came from Ariwara of the Province of Yamato, Uji in the Province of Yamashiro, Ise, Kyoto or Bitchu.

sen.j: 大和在原説と山城宇治説は『北条五代記』に異説として紹介されたもので有力視はされなかった。
sen.e: Aiwara in Yamato Province and Uji in Yamashiro Province were two candidates introduced as divergent views in the "Hojo Godaiki (History of 5 generations of the Hojo clan)" but did not become prevailing theories.

sen.j: 伊勢説は『北条記』『相州兵乱記』に書かれており、早雲が信濃国守護小笠原定基に宛てた書状で「伊勢の関氏と同族である」と書いていたことを根拠に1901年に藤井継平が主張し、田中義成がこれを支持した。
sen.e: The Ise theory comes from the "Hojoki" and "Soshu Heiranki," and asserted by a scholar, Tsugihei FUJII, with the reasoning that Soun sent a letter to Sadamoto OGASAWARA, guard for the Province of Shinano, that "I belong to the same family as the Seki clan of Ise," which won the support of the historian, Yoshinari TANAKA.

The Ise theory, based on a letter Soun sent to Sadamoto OGASAWARA, Governor of Shinano Province, stating "I belong to the same family as the Seki Clan of Ise," that appears in the "Hojoki" and the "Soshu Heiranki," was advocated in 1901 by the scholar, Tsugihei FUJII, and supported by the historian, Yoshinari TANAKA.

sen.j: これに対して渡辺世祐は『寛政重修諸家譜』などにある幕府政所執事の京都伊勢氏の出身で、伊勢貞親の弟伊勢貞藤またはその子供であろうとする京都説を主張した。
sen.e: On the other hand, another historian, Yosuke WATANABE, asserted that Soun originated from Kyoto-Ise clan, a steward for the Bakufu government as stated in the "Kansei Choshushokafu," and Soun was the same person as Sadafuji ISE, Sadachika ISE's younger brother, or his son.

On the other hand, another historian, Yosuke WATANABE, asserted that Soun originated from the Kyoto-Ise Clan, was a steward for the Bakufu government as stated in the "Kansei Choshushokafu," and that Soun was either the same person as Sadafuji ISE, Sadachika ISE's younger brother, or his son.

On the other hand, another historian, Yosuke WATANABE, asserted that Soun originated from the Kyoto-Ise clan, was a steward for the Bakufu government as stated in the "Kansei Choshushokafu," and that Soun was either the same person as Sadafuji ISE, Sadachika ISE's younger brother, or his son.

sen.j: 備中説は『今川記』および『太閤記』に書かれており、井原市法泉寺の古文書を調査した藤井駿が1956年に早雲を備中伊勢氏で将軍足利義尚の側近であった「伊勢新九郎盛時」とする論文を発表した。
sen.e: The Bitchu theory is written in the "Imagawa-ki "and "Taikoki," and Shun FUJII who had researched the old documents at Hosen-ji Temple in Ihara City, published a paper in 1956 stating that Soun had been the Shinkuro Moritoki ISE, who was an attendant to Shogun Yoshinao Ashikaga.

sen.j: 1980年前後に奥野高広、今谷明、小和田哲男が史料調査の結果として「伊勢新九郎盛時」を後の北条早雲とする論文を発表した。
sen.e: Some time around 1980, Takahiro OKUNO, Akira IMATANI and Tetsuo OWADA published a paper stating that as a result of historical research, Shinkuro Moritoki ISE later became Soun HOJO.

sen.j: 永享4年（1432年）生れだと近年有力視された幕臣伊勢盛時の父盛定の活動時期とも伊勢貞親（盛時の母の兄弟）の甥という系譜関係も成り立たなくなる。
sen.e: If he had been born in 1423, the theories about the active period of Morisada, father of Moritoki ISE, retainer to the Shogun's or that he was the nephew of Sadachika ISE (Moritoki's mother's brother) would not stand.

If he had been born in 1423, the theories about the active period of Morisada, father of the shogunate retainer Moritoki ISE, or about his being the nephew of Sadachika ISE (Moritoki's mother's brother) would not stand.

sen.e: If he had been born in 1432, the theories about the active period of Morisada, father of the shogunate retainer Moritoki ISE, or about his being the nephew of Sadachika ISE (Moritoki's mother's brother) would not stand.

sen.j: これは長年、早雲と思われた伊勢貞藤の生年と混同されてしまった結果であるとし、江戸時代前期成立の軍記物で「子の年」生まれと記載されている。
sen.e: The discrepancy resulted from confusion with the date of birth of Sadafuji ISE, who was once thought to be Soun, and from a war chronicles written at the beginning of Edo Period, in which Soun was described as having been born in the year of Rat.

sen.j: 姉の北川殿の結婚時期と考え合わせて、24歳若い康正2年（1456年）生まれであろうとした。
sen.e: Considering the date of his sister Kitagawa-Dono's marriage, he must have been 24 years younger than the conventional theory holds(born 1456).

sen.j: これだと、姉の北川殿の結婚の時期に11歳頃、駿河下向時点で32歳、享年は64歳となり、当時の人間の活動としては妥当な年齢であることから、有力視されるようになった。
sen.e: With this age, Soun would have been 11 when Kitagawa-Dono got married, 32 when he went to Suruga and 64 at the time of his death, common for the man of that time.

sen.j: しかしながら、この説については未だ検討中の段階で、これを採らず享年88説を採る研究者もいる。
sen.e: However, this theory is still being examined, and there are researchers who still insist that Soun died at the age of 88.

sen.j: 最近の小説や評論の類それにインターネットのホームページも早雲を「大器晩成」の典型として享年88説を採っているものが多く、必ずしも一般に定着した訳ではない。
sen.e: Recent novels, reviews and postings on the Internet still maintain that Soun was a man who bloomed late in life and died at the age of 88, and neither of the above theories have been established among the general public.

sen.j: (ちなみに、近世以前の平均寿命の短さは乳幼児死亡率の高さが主な原因であり、成人男子の平均余命だけを考えれば現代人より著しく短い訳ではない。
sen.e: (As a reference, the average life expectancy in that period was lower than today, not because the people then died at an earlier age but because of the high infant mortality rate and the average life of an adult male was not significantly shorter than that of today.

sen.j: 作家などは身分が低く人生の辛酸を舐め、十分に老成した人間でなければ早雲のような活躍はできまいと長年論じてきた。
sen.e: Some writers have long argued that only a fully mature man who have been born low and had lived a hard life would be able to win the success that Soun did.

sen.j: 近年の研究を反映した早雲像は全く別であり、将軍に直接仕える名門一族の青年が幕府の命を帯びて駿河に下り、中央の政治と連動しながら関東で活躍して、後北条氏の祖となったことになる。
sen.e: The image of Soun reflecting studies made in recent years is completely different; a man who had served the Shogun received order from the Bakufu to go to Suruga, and ruled over Kanto in collaboration with the central government, and later became a member of the Go-Hojo clan.

The image of Soun seen in recent studies is completely different; a young man from a noted family who served the Shogun received an order from the Bakufu to go to Suruga, ruled over Kanto in collaboration with the central government and later became a member of the Go-Hojo clan.

sen.e: The image of Soun seen in recent studies is completely different; a young man from a noted family who served the Shogun received an order from the Bakufu to go to Suruga, ruled over Kanto in collaboration with the central government and later became a member of the Gohojo clan.

sen.j: これらの新説が、主な小説やメディアでは以下のように扱われている。

sen.j: 司馬遼太郎の『箱根の坂』（1984年）では、その時期の研究を反映して単純な伊勢素浪人とせず、備中伊勢氏とし、政所執事伊勢貞親の屋敷に寄宿しながら京で足利義視に仕える設定である。
sen.e: In Ryotaro Shiba's novel "Hakone-no-saka (The Slopes of Hakone)" (1984), he reflects the studies of time and is presented not as simple master-less samurai of Ise, but as a samurai of the Bitchu-Ise clan serving Yoshimi AHIKAGA while residing in the residence of Sadachika ISE, a steward of the Shogun.

Ryotaro SHIBA's novel, "Hakone-no-saka (The Slopes of Hakone)" (1984), reflects the studies of time and Soun is presented not as a simple ronin of Ise, but as a samurai of the Bitchu-Ise clan, serving Yoshimi AHIKAGA while residing in the residence of Sadachika ISE, a steward of the Shogun.

sen.j: しかしながら、大衆小説として「身分の低い素浪人」のイメージを守り、早雲を伊勢氏の末流とし、鞍作りを業にする職人的人物として描かれている。
sen.e: At the same time, he maintained the image held by the general public of his being a lowly samurai, by presenting him as the descendent of the Ise clan and a saddle maker.

sen.j: 2005年放送の「その時歴史が動いた：戦国をひらいた男～北条早雲 56才からの挑戦～」（日本放送協会、ゲスト：小和田哲男静岡大学教授）では、早雲を幕府の高級官僚としているが、年齢については享年88説を採り「大器晩成」として描いている（諸説を検討の結果一般的な説を採用したとのこと）。
sen.e: In the documentary, "Movement of History: The Man that started the Warring States Period - Soun HOJO, Challenge from the age of 56" (NHK, Guest: Tetsuo OWADA, Professor of Shizuoka University), broadcasted in 2005, Soun is described as a late bloomer who became of a high ranking officer in the Bakufu government and who died at the age of 88 (a generally accepted theory that was adopted after reviewing various theories).

sen.j: 1980年代以前の小説や一般向け書籍では、早雲を「非常に長命な大器晩成」「徒手空拳の素浪人」として書かれているものが多く、海音寺潮五郎の早雲の史伝などは典型である。
sen.e: Most of novels and books for general public published during and after 1980s describe Soun as "a man who bloomed late and lived a long life" and as "a master-less samurai who had built himself up from nothing," with Chogoro KAIONJI's historical legend being the typical.
